> Sure, how about a Java ME application?

I visited Ward Cunningham a few years ago.  He took me to his  
basement and showed me a cute little DSP chip that he had programmed  
in assembler to draw concentric circles on a TV screen.  The program  
simply manipulated a D/A converter to generate the video signal.  Cute.

Then he said, "Now, how would you do this using TDD?"  He proceeded  
to show me a java program, complete with tests, that simulated the  
generation of the video signal, complete with the concentric  
circles.  The program he wrote was, in a way, a DSP simulator.  But  
it was more than that.  In essence he created an array of objects  
that correlated roughly to DSP instructions.  Each of these objects  
had two derivatives.  One mimicked the behavior of the DSP  
instruction that it represented, and the other emitted corresponding  
DSP assembly language to an output file.

The result was a very detailed DSP application, on a chip that did  
not support a high level language, written in Java using TDD.

Where there is a will, there is a way.
